author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand hosts 50,000 fans in its largest concert since the pandemic began.
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — More than 50,000 fans packed into Eden Park stadium, New Zealand’s largest, on Saturday night for what is believed to be the largest live in-person concert since the pandemic began.
content: AUCKLAND, New Zealand — More than 50,000 fans packed into Eden Park stadium, New Zealand’s largest, on Saturday night for what is believed to be the largest live in-person concert since the pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Taijuan Walker Dominates Nationals for His First Mets Win
description: The right-hander allowed three hits in seven innings. A rough start by Jameson Taillon prevented the Yankees from sweeping Cleveland.
content: Taijuan Walker pitched three-hit ball over seven innings in his first win of the season, J.D. Davis hit a two-run homer in the first off a faltering Patrick Corbin and the Mets beat Washington, 4-0, Sunday to take two of three in the matchup of N.L. East rivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Time to Buy (or Sell) a House?
description: Should you buy (or sell) a house right now? Record numbers of Americans are asking the same question.
content: Good morning. Have you gotten your vaccine yet? The Biden administration is offering tax breaks to companies that give their workers paid time off to get their shot. Here’s what else you should know in business and tech for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas E. Ricks
title: Malcolm Gladwell on the Hard Decisions of War
description: Gladwell’s “The Bomber Mafia” looks at the air campaign against Japan in World War II and finds a surprising hero in Curtis LeMay.
content: THE BOMBER MAFIAA Dream, a Temptation, and the Longest Night of the Second World WarBy Malcolm Gladwell
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Millions Are Skipping Their Second Doses of Covid Vaccines
description: Nearly 8 percent of those who got initial Pfizer or Moderna shots missed their second doses. State officials want to prevent the numbers from rising.
content: Millions of Americans are not getting the second doses of their Covid-19 vaccines, and their ranks are growing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: $1 Million in Toxic Bleach Sold as ‘Miracle’ Cure, Officials Say
description: A Florida grand jury indicted a man and his three sons, accusing them of marketing an “unproven and potentially harmful” solution as a remedy for Covid-19, cancer, autism and more.
content: MIAMI — Leaders of a business masquerading as a church sold a toxic bleach solution as a religious sacrament and marketed it as a “miracle” cure for Covid-19, cancer, autism, Alzheimer’s disease and more, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: ‘Chlorinated’ U.S. Chickens Convince British Consumers the Sky Is Falling
description: Denounced by politicians and reviled by food safety activists, American-bred “chlorinated chickens” have become a symbol of all the U.K. fears about a looming trade deal.
content: LONDON — In this post-Brexit, mid-pandemic moment in the United Kingdom, with its economy battered by recession and the royal family in mourning and turmoil, it is hard to find a topic that unites this fractious nation. But U.S. chickens — yes, the lowly, clucking farm animal, consumed daily by the millions in all 50 states — have done it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David D. Kirkpatrick
title: Split-Second Decisions: How a Supreme Court Case Shaped Modern Policing
description: Officers using deadly force rely on a legal doctrine set forth decades ago. Now, the movement launched by the death of George Floyd is trying to change that standard.
content: In case after case, it took only a split second for an officer to pull the trigger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Half a Year After Trump’s Defeat, Arizona Republicans Are Recounting the Vote
description: An audit of the vote in Arizona’s most populous county was meant to mollify angry Trump voters. But it is being criticized as a partisan exercise more than a fact-finding one.
content: PHOENIX — It seemed so simple back in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Lee
title: Teach Your Kids to Resist Hatred Toward Asians
description: Books make great educational resources to combat discrimination and xenophobia, and to foster activism.
content: After a year with a marked increase in  discrimination and harassment aimed at Asian-Americans across the country, the past few months have been particularly shocking, in both the frequency and violence of  attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Vanessa Friedman
title: Alber Elbaz, Beloved Fashion Designer, Is Dead at 59
description: A favorite of celebrities like Meryl Streep and Natalie Portman, he rejuvenated Lanvin and had recently started his own brand. He died of Covid-19.
content: Alber Elbaz, a Moroccan-born Israeli fashion designer who rejuvenated Lanvin and had recently started a new venture, AZ Factory, died on Saturday in Paris. He was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Summer camp advice — keep masks and distancing — gets an update from the C.D.C.
description: The updated guidance was issued just weeks before many U.S. camps resume operations in mid-May.
content: Children going to camp this summer can be within three feet of peers in the same-group settings, but they must wear masks at all times, federal health officials say. The only times children should remove their masks is when they are swimming, napping, eating or drinking; they should be spaced far apart for these activities, positioned head to toe for naps and seated at least six feet apart for meals, snacks and water breaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: U.S. to Send Virus-Ravaged India Materials for Vaccines
description: The Biden administration, under pressure to help with a surge raging out of control, will also supply therapeutics, test kits, ventilators and protective gear.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration, under increasing pressure to address a devastating surge of the coronavirus in India, said on Sunday that it had partially lifted a ban on the export of raw materials for vaccines and would also supply India with therapeutics, rapid diagnostic test kits, ventilators and personal protective gear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elouise Wilson, Mary R. Benally, Ahjani Yepa and Cynthia Wilson
title: Women of Bears Ears Are Asking You to Help Save It
description: Will sacred lands protected by President Obama be protected once again?
content: We are among the Women of Bears Ears — Indigenous women who support our families and communities in the protections of ancestral lands. We come from Diné, Nuche, Pueblo and other allied Native Nations. From these Southwestern lands, twin buttes rise; they are known as Bears Ears.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 25, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 25, 2021.
content: An article on Page 9 this weekend about Marianne Faithfull misstates the occupation of her  husband John Dunbar. He is an artist, not a writer. An earlier version also mistakenly referenced the armistice in relation to Faithfull’s year of birth. She was born a year after the end of World War II, not World War I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Rural Ambulance Crews Have Run Out of Money and Volunteers
description: Strained by pandemic-era budget cuts, stress and a lack of revenue, at least 10 ambulance companies in Wyoming are in danger of shuttering — some imminently.
content: WORLAND, Wyo. — For three years, Luke Sypherd has run the small volunteer ambulance crew that services Washakie County, Wyo., caring for the county’s 7,800 residents and, when necessary, transporting them 162 miles north to the nearest major trauma center, in Billings, Mont.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Why Are Democrats Pushing a Tax Cut for the Wealthy?
description: Restoring an unlimited federal tax deduction for state and local tax payments is bad politics and bad policy.
content: Democrats struck a chord with voters in the 2020 elections by campaigning on the need for the wealthiest Americans to pay higher taxes. Now the party is flirting with a major change in tax policy that would allow the wealthiest Americans to pay lower taxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: U.S. Military Begins Final Withdrawal From Afghanistan
description: The top American commander, Gen. Austin S. Miller, says he is often asked whether the Afghan forces are ready to fight the Taliban alone. His answer? ‘They must be ready.’
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The U.S. military has begun its complete withdrawal from Afghanistan, the top American commander there said Sunday, marking what amounts to the beginning of the end of the United States’ nearly 20-year-old war in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Overdue VHS Tape From 1999 Leads to Warrant for Embezzlement
description: The charge was related to a “Sabrina the Teenage Witch” tape that had been rented from a video store in Norman, Okla. Prosecutors dismissed the case on Wednesday.
content: They once dotted shopping plazas in America with ubiquity, beckoning binge watchers with shelves of VHS cassettes, microwave popcorn and boxes of candy — and a reminder to “Be Kind, Rewind.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel J. Wakin
title: Christa Ludwig, Mezzo-Soprano of Velvety Hues, Is Dead at 93
description: She was a beloved interpreter of Strauss, Mozart and Wagner roles, but equally admired for her rendition of art songs.
content: Christa Ludwig, who poured a lustrous voice into dramatically taut performances of opera roles — especially those of Mozart, Strauss and Wagner — and intimately rendered art songs as one of the premier mezzo-sopranos of the second half of the 20th century, died on Saturday at her home in Klosterneuburg, Austria. She was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Sarah Hughes
title: Johnson & Johnson, India, Mushrooms: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Arlene Pieper Stine, 90, Dies; First Woman to Finish a Marathon
description: She ran the challenging Pikes Peak Marathon in Colorado in 1959. For the next 50 years she had no idea that she had made sports history.
content: On Aug. 7, 1959, Arlene Pieper completed the Pikes Peak Marathon, a grueling mountain course in Manitou Springs, Col., that no other woman had finished in its brief history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Niu and Emily Rhyne
title: 4 Takeaways From Our Investigation Into ICE’s Mishandling of Covid-19
description: The Times found a pattern of neglect and secrecy that helped fuel outbreaks both inside and outside ICE detention facilities.
content: The United States currently has the largest immigration detention system in the world. On any given day, Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or ICE, holds tens of thousands of people in about 200 facilities across the country. And throughout the pandemic, these facilities have become some of the most dangerous places in the United States when it comes to Covid-19 outbreaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Dore and Robert Vinluan
title: Look How Far Weave Come
description: On the first anniversary of the At Home section, zigzag through this puzzle to reveal the twist.
content: This week is the one-year anniversary of the At Home section, and what better way to celebrate than with a puzzle containing a hidden picture? Solve the clues and reveal the twist, with a mini shout-out to the section’s basket-weaving activity from August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: E.U. Set to Let Vaccinated U.S. Tourists Visit This Summer
description: The head of the European Commission said the bloc would switch policy, under certain conditions, after more than a year of mostly banning nonessential travel.
content: BRUSSELS — American tourists who have been fully vaccinated against Covid-19 will be able to visit the European Union over the summer, the head of the bloc’s executive body said in an interview with The New York Times on Sunday, more than a year after shutting down nonessential travel from most countries to limit the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Eric Adams Endorsed by Top Bronx Leader, Giving Him Lift With Latinos
description: The endorsement from Ruben Diaz Jr., the Bronx borough president, could help Mr. Adams reach Latino and Bronx voters in the New York City mayor’s race.
content: When Ruben Diaz Jr. dropped out of the New York City mayor’s race last year, his decision surprised many. He had the support of the powerful Bronx Democratic Party, an alliance with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and strong ties to Latino voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Behind ‘Strange Fruit,’ Billie Holiday’s Anti-Lynching Anthem
description: It helped make Holiday a star, but it was written by Abel Meeropol, a teacher in the Bronx. An Oscar nomination and a year of protests against racism have kept it in the conversation.
content: When Billie Holiday first performed “Strange Fruit” in 1939, the song was so bold for the time that she could sing it only in certain places where it was safe to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Sarah Mervosh
title: Michigan’s Covid Wards Are Filling Up With Younger Patients
description: Even as vaccines roll out, more younger people in Michigan are being hospitalized than at any other point in the pandemic. And they’re coming in sicker.
content: ROYAL OAK, Mich. — At Beaumont Hospital, Royal Oak, in one of America’s worst coronavirus hot spots, entire units are still filled with Covid-19 patients. People weak with the virus still struggle to sit up in bed. And the phone still rings with pleas to transfer patients on the verge of death to units with higher-tech equipment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘While I Was Away, My Boss Had Flowers Delivered to My Apartment’
description: Something to celebrate, a rolling card game and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: India may be underreporting coronavirus numbers.
content: Each day, India reports more than 300,000 new infections, a world record that accounts for nearly half of all new cases in a global surge, and more than 2,000 deaths. But experts say those numbers represent just a fraction of the true human toll from the virus in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Bob Fass, Pioneer of Underground Radio, Dies at 87
description: His provocative “Radio Unnameable,” long a staple of the New York station WBAI, offered a home on the FM dial to everyone from Abbie Hoffman to Tiny Tim.
content: Bob Fass, who for more than 50 years hosted an anarchic and influential radio show on New York’s countercultural FM station WBAI that mixed political conversation, avant-garde music, serendipitous encounters and outright agitation, died on Saturday in Monroe, N.C., where he lived in recent years. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Learning Caution From a Late Columnist
description: Sometimes we misjudge the meaning of events unfolding around us.
content: There have been many columnists for The New York Times, many of whom I have only heard or read about, some legendary in their skill and influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: ‘Nothing Short of Amazing’: NASA Mars Helicopter Makes Longest Flight Yet
description: Ingenuity made a 328-foot round-trip journey, helping to demonstrate the capability of the vehicle’s navigation system.
content: NASA’s Mars helicopter went up again, going faster and traveling a total distance that was about the length of an American football field on its third trip through the wispy air of Mars.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: As Covid Ravages India, True Toll Is Undercounted
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 25, 2021.
content: “Why would a private hospital connive with the government in hiding the real death numbers? It was an organized crime. It was an illegal act.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louise Donovan
title: Domestic Workers in Gulf Countries Vent Woes on TikTok
description: Foreign employees in wealthy households — most of them women — have been using the video-sharing app to bring abuses to light.
content: The young Kenyan housekeeper, dressed in a crisp uniform and a head scarf, nods her head from side to side to the beat of a tune in her video, an expression of mock exasperation on her face as she stares into the camera and mimes the refrain: “Don’t got it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Hussein Mohamed
title: Gunfire Erupts in Mogadishu as Somalia’s Political Feud Turns Violent
description: Tensions had been rising since the president, a former American citizen, failed to hold scheduled elections, then extended his term in office by two years.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Gunfire erupted across the Somali capital, Mogadishu, on Sunday as security forces loyal to the president clashed with units that appeared to have sided with his rivals, stoking fears that Somalia’s simmering political crisis is spilling over into violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Deb Amlen
title: Soiree, Say
description: “Alma mater of five U.S. presidents”
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — This is Eric Bornstein’s fifth puzzle for The New York Times. To mark the occasion, he has a very special collaborator: his mother, Lori.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Adam Dean
title: Phuket Was Poised for Tourism Comeback. A Covid Surge Dashed Those Hopes.
description: Phuket, one of Thailand’s top tourist havens, had an ambitious plan to reopen to the world this summer. But with a spike in cases, the island’s desperate situation is unlikely to end anytime soon.
content: PHUKET, Thailand — Around the corner from the teeth-whitening clinic and the tattoo parlor with offerings in Russian, Hebrew and Chinese, near the outdoor eatery with indifferent fried rice meant to fuel sunburned tourists or tired go-go dancers, the Hooters sign has lost its H.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: How to Get Back Into the Job Market
description: Many job seekers don’t know where to look after the year we’ve just had. If you count yourself among this crowd, here’s how to get back into the market, even if you’re feeling rusty.
content: Airlines are canceling flights because they don’t have enough pilots to fly them. Restaurants are posting open positions on their Instagram feeds. Even the local grocery store has a “hiring” sign out front. Welcome to spring 2021: After a year of being battered by the pandemic, the economy is finally showing signs of a strong, steady recovery, and jobs are popping up like crocuses. Employers added almost a million positions in March alone, according to the Labor Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Falih Hassan and Jane Arraf
title: Fire at Baghdad Hospital Packed With Covid Patients Kills at Least 82
description: A blaze set off by an exploding oxygen cylinder swept through a hospital that lacked smoke detectors or sprinklers. More are expected to die from severe burns.
content: BAGHDAD — A fire sparked by an exploding oxygen cylinder killed at least 82 people, most of them Covid-19 patients and their relatives, at a Baghdad hospital late Saturday, a devastating example of the pandemic’s impact on a country riddled with corruption, mismanagement and a legacy of decrepit infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Fauci and other top U.S. health officials stress the urgency of vaccinations and their safety.
description: Now that the J&J pause has lifted, the government is pushing to get most adult Americans inoculated this summer.
content: Top U.S. health officials sought to reassure Americans on Sunday that the 10-day pause in the use of Johnson & Johnson’s vaccine showed how well safety monitoring for the Covid-19 vaccines worked, and should not add to the hesitancy to get shots among some Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller and Michael Levenson
title: Deputy Shoots Unarmed Man Repeatedly During 911 Call, Officials Say
description: Isaiah Brown was on a cordless phone with an emergency dispatcher when he was shot, his lawyer said. His family said he was in intensive care.
content: A Virginia sheriff’s deputy shot and seriously wounded an unarmed man early on Wednesday morning, less than an hour after the deputy had given the man a ride after his car broke down, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman and Lindsey Underwood
title: Oscars 2021 Red Carpet: A Guide to How to Watch and Best Looks
description: The Academy Awards are back. But they may look a little different.
content: [Follow live coverage of the Oscars 2021 and winners list.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Get a head start on Mother’s Day with two new puff pastry tarts from Melissa Clark.
content: Good morning. My mother loathed Mother’s Day. She thought it a holiday ginned up by the greeting-card industrial complex, the flowers and brunch cartel. Still, if she were around, a gajillion months into this pandemic that would have kept her from her children and grandchildren, I think she would have demanded some sort of vaccinated audience this year. (She died in 2019.) I don’t think she’d be alone. This year’s Mother’s Day, two weeks from today, is going to be serious business for a lot of families. They’ve been apart. Now, perhaps, they can be together, carefully.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: U.S. to send vaccine materials and other supplies to hard-hit India, officials say.
description: Previously, Biden administration officials had pushed back as pressure mounted for the U.S. to help combat the surge in India.
content: The Biden administration, under increasing pressure to address a devastating surge of the coronavirus in India, said on Sunday that it had partially lifted a ban on the export of raw materials for vaccines and would also supply India with therapeutics, rapid diagnostic test kits, ventilators and personal protective gear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh and Paul Mozur
title: As Outbreak Rages, India Orders Critical Social Media Posts to Be Taken Down
description: Aimed at Facebook, Twitter and Instagram, the move sets up a clash over free speech amid a widening political and public health crisis.
content: NEW DELHI — With a devastating second wave of Covid-19 sweeping across India and lifesaving supplemental oxygen in short supply, India’s government on Sunday said it ordered Facebook, Instagram and Twitter to take down dozens of social media posts critical of its handling of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Block Association’ Review: Yes, in Your Backyard
description: In this clever show, audience members join a “neighborhood” and lobby for how its discordant residents should to spend a chunk of community money.
content: Mister Rogers was wrong: It isn’t always a beautiful day in the neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damon Beres
title: Your Smartphone Should Be Built to Last
description: A movement is underway to slow the obsolescence of our electronic gear.
content: Years from now, what creature will digest the new iPads and AirTags that Apple announced on Tuesday? What soil will absorb their metals?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi
title: Explore Coral Reefs and Enjoy Flower Arrangements Inspired by Art
description: This week, watch a puppetry performance, break your Ramadan fast with a virtual open mic and iftar or listen to music from Yosmel Montejo and Vox Sambou.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Howard Students Protest Cut of Classics Department, Hub for Black Scholarship
description: Howard University’s board of trustees approved the decision to scrap the program, the only such department at a historically Black university.
content: As an alumna of Howard University, Anika Prather remembers feeling that the classics were everywhere during her years as a student. No matter your major or field of study, she recalled, it was practically a given that classics would be woven into your educational experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: We’re All Crypto People Now
description: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies have gone from curiosity to punchline to viable investment, making them almost impossible to ignore — for better or worse.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — On Monday evening, a few days after a large cryptocurrency exchange listed its shares on the stock market, several hundred women gathered in a virtual conference room to talk about Bitcoin. Claire Wasserman, a co-founder of Ladies Get Paid, the company that co-hosted the event, marveled at the turnout, noting it showed “how committed you all are to getting wealthy.” She described a sweeping change in the way we live, work and transact — all driven by crypto. “I don’t want you to miss out on the future,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eyal Press
title: There’s a Step Biden Can Take to Help Workers, and He Hasn’t Done It
description: The Labor Department still (still!) needs to do more to protect employees from getting Covid on the job.
content: Since foiling Donald Trump’s bid for a second term, Joe Biden has gone out of his way to send working-class voters the message that he, and not his predecessor, is the true champion of their interests. Shortly after he was inaugurated, Mr. Biden signed an executive order to encourage the federal government and federal contractors to pay their workers a $15 minimum hourly wage. He fired the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, an anti-union lawyer and a Trump appointee. In a video tweeted in late February, Mr. Biden paid homage to unions and warned employers that there should be “no intimidation, no coercion, no threats” when workers exercise their collective bargaining rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Federal Aid to Renters Moves Slowly, Leaving Many at Risk
description: Congress allocated $25 billion in December and another $21 billion in March to help people who fell behind on rent during the pandemic. Little has reached landlords or tenants.
content: WASHINGTON — Four months after Congress approved tens of billions of dollars in emergency rental aid, only a small portion has reached landlords and tenants, and in many places it is impossible even to file an application.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Gerrit Cole Outduels Shane Bieber as Yankees Top Cleveland
description: The Yankees’ ace struck out 11 and allowed just three hits. The Mets, meanwhile, got crushed by Washington.
content: CLEVELAND — Gerrit Cole was one pitch better than Shane Bieber in a heavyweight matchup of aces as Rougned Odor and Aaron Hicks homered off Cleveland’s Cy Young Award winner in the fifth inning, giving the Yankees a 2-1 win over Cleveland on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 26, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The “Herald Square Bomber” Who Wasn’t’
description: After the Sept. 11 attacks, U.S. authorities used informants to secure terror convictions. But did they help create plots where none existed?
content: In summer 2003, Shahawar Matin Siraj, then 21 and working at an Islamic bookstore in New York, met Osama Eldawoody, a nuclear engineer twice his age. To Mr. Siraj’s delight they struck up an unlikely friendship — never before had someone this sophisticated taken him so seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz, Andrea Kannapell and Bryan Pietsch
title: Cases remain high in the U.S., but vaccinations are slowing.
description: The average number of vaccine shots given each day, which rose for months and peaked at 3.38 million, has now fallen to 2.86 million, the lowest level since March 31.
content: Vaccination rates are falling in the United States, despite the spread of highly contagious virus variants that are fueling a national caseload that remains high enough to underscore concerns of the potential for a new surge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Rose Namajunas Retakes U.F.C. Title by Defeating Chinese Star Zhang Weili
description: The American took Zhang down in Jacksonville, Fla., in less than 90 seconds. Kamaru Usman retained his welterweight title against Jorge Masvidal.
content: Rose Namajunas knocked out Zhang Weili to recapture the Ultimate Fighting Championship women’s strawweight title on Saturday night in Jacksonville, Fla., during what was billed as the first full-capacity sporting event held indoors in the United States in more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: How to Watch the Oscars 2021: Date, Time and Streaming
description: A guide to everything you need to know for the 93rd annual Academy Awards on Sunday night.
content: [Follow live coverage of the 2021 Oscars and winners list.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Killer of French Police Officer Was a Radicalized Islamist, Prosecutor Says
description: The attacker watched videos ‘glorifying martyrs and jihad’ immediately before the stabbing, the official said.
content: PARIS — Jamel Gorchene, the Tunisian man who killed a police officer Friday in a terrorist attack that has stirred a political storm in France, had watched videos “glorifying martyrs and jihad immediately before he acted,” the top French antiterrorism prosecutor said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: India’s Fashion Artisans Face ‘Extreme Distress’ in Pandemic
description: The working conditions of the so-called karigars, who make handicrafts for luxury brands, have long been an issue. Now many have no job at all.
content: Saddam Sekh used to be a floor supervisor at a steamy Indian workshop in Mumbai that produced orders for an exporter working with some of the biggest names in luxury fashion, including Dior and Gucci. Day and night, he would watch as the karigars — an Urdu term for the highly skilled artisans who specialize in handicrafts like embroidery, beading and appliqué — stitched designer gowns destined for the Hollywood red carpet, or ornate samples for runway shows in Milan and Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: Kevin McCarthy, Four Months After Jan. 6, Still on Defensive Over Trump
description: But Mr. McCarthy, the House Republican leader who could become speaker after 2022, says he needs to work with Donald Trump, who “goes up and down with his anger.’’
content: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Kevin McCarthy, the House Republican leader, was in an uncharacteristically dark place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: N.F.L. Draft 2021: After Trevor Lawrence, Pick Another Quarterback
description: With no shortage of teams looking for a passer to build around, Zach Wilson, Justin Fields, Trey Lance and Mac Jones figure to shape the draft’s top 10 picks.
content: There is no drama as to who will be the No. 1 pick in this year’s N.F.L. draft. The only question had been which team would get the chance to draft Clemson quarterback Trevor Lawrence. The Jacksonville Jaguars secured that honor by way of the Jets’ seemingly not understanding that they were supposed to keep losing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David L. Kirp
title: A 4-Year-Old Child Is Not a Problem. And Expulsion Is Not a Solution.
description: There is an effective approach to breaking the preschool-to-prison pipeline.
content: The boy I’ll call Jackson is the kind of youngster who drives a preschool teacher around the bend. The 4-year-old bites and hits other children, and curses out his teacher, Mariana Lopez. During circle time, when the class is supposed to cluster around and listen to one another, he is a hellion, and nap time turns into a pitched battle. Preschool teachers rely on parents to relate what’s happening on the home front, but Jackson’s mom refused to meet with Ms. Lopez because she felt her son was being persecuted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What the Stars Wore on the Oscars Red Carpet
description: A socially distanced promenade: nominees posed without their usual entourages, and were interviewed at a remove of six feet.
content: A socially distanced promenade: nominees posed without their usual entourages, and were interviewed at a remove of six feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Niu, Emily Rhyne and Aaron Byrd
title: How ICE’s Mishandling of Covid-19 Fueled Outbreaks Around the Country
description: To date, Immigration and Customs Enforcement has reported over 12,000 virus cases. Our investigation found that the impact of infection extended beyond U.S. detention centers.
content: To date, Immigration and Customs Enforcement has reported over 12,000 virus cases. Our investigation found that the impact of infection extended beyond U.S. detention centers.
